## Web: https://nirantk.com/projectnoor/

We're exploring the NCERT History & Civics Textbooks in new machine-augmented ways to see both:

1. What we are being taught in terms of personalities and places? -- from an inward lens -- @NirantK is the one to mention in your issues. 
2. How we can explore existing topics and re-discover the connections between them? -- @meghanabhange is the one to mention in your issues. 

For question 1, Questions we are interested in answering:

```
    - Race, Ethnicity and Gender were the questions of interest in the original paper
    - People
        - Origin
            - Europeans
            - Indian Subcontinent
        - Era
            - 1000-1500 AD
            - 1500-1857 AD
            - 1857-1929 AD
            - Before 1947
            - Post 1947
        - Gender
            - Male
            - Female
            - Unspecified
        - Profession
            - Scientists, Mathematicians, Explorers and Engineers
            - Artists, Poets, Sportsperson
            - Politicians, Freedom Fighters
    - Topics and Terms
    - __Can we do a people to idea mapping/correlation?__
    - Places
        - Within India: States, Cities
        - Indian Subcontinent
        - Outside India
    - Common Claims
        1. Mentions by Gender
        2. Regional differences in topic: 
        3. Origin differences: South Indian vs North Indian names
        4. Origin differences: Europe vs India
        5. Profession
```

- Original Inspiration from the work by #[[Dan Jurafsky]] et al
    - https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/2332858420940312
    - Extend this to Indian books, class 5 to 12, all subjects for NCERT
    - Domain: whatarewetaught.com 
    - Computational Social Science / CSS-NLP track at EMNLP
    - Code: https://github.com/ddemszky/textbook-analysis
    - Slide Deck: https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1QQuPxbqvBSWePCSAWDoPkcTpXgONvVAhciKT8Uqwys0/edit#slide=id.p3
        - Research Questions defines the scope and nature of questions they are interested in asking
        - They used Abby OCR after scanning the books -- which must have been tedious and error prone. Since we're mostly using official pdfs, we should face less of this problem. 
        - The limited themselves to the top 15 history textbooks alone. That's just one subject!
